history.content:
Law Schools use a system called LSDAS to calculate your GPA based on undergraduate institution. Given that UC Berkeley lapses Incompletes to Fs after a semester, we can assume they are considered "punitive", and they will possibly be factored negatively into your GPA. When considering graduate school, the most reliable source of information is always to directly contact law school admission offices. You could also try Lauri, the Legal Studies Major Adviser or Grace Kim at the Career Center.

Keep in mind that if you received an incomplete because of exceptional circumstances, you will have a chance on your law school application to explain any discrepancies on your transcript.

My guess is that they calculate this punitively into your GPA, but I can't be sure. When considering graduate school, the most reliable source of information is always to directly contact law school admission offices. You could also try Lauri, the Legal Studies Major Adviser.

children.subject: My guess is that it's still factored punitively, but like I said, you'd have to check.
What about if you "freeze" the incomplete grade using the petition, and leave the I grade permanently?

history.content: Does law school consider a frozen "Incomplete" grade punitive or non punitive?
history.subject: Freezing an Incomplete
